questions.text: A 28 y G2P1 presents to the OPD with a missed period and history of mild spotting PV. A urine pregnancy test done at home shows 2 lines. All are possible diagnosis except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Complete Abortion

 

  • Complete Abortion will present with heavy bleeding with the passage of fleshy tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Placental sign or implantation bleeding will have minimal bleeding
  • Threatened and missed abortion will only have spotting or minimal bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of Spontaneous Abortion

 

 

Ref: Page No: 159 DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics; 9th edition

questions.text: A 24-y woman presents to the emergency with a history of amenorrhea for 2.5 months. She complains of abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding since a day. On examination her PR and BP are normal. Abdominal examination reveals mild tenderness. On speculum examination, there is bleeding from the cervical os. Bimanual examination reveals a 10 weeks uterus and the cervix admits 1 finger. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Inevitable abortion

 

  • In the given scenario, there is no passage of fleshy mass; the cervical os is open and the uterus corresponds to the POG – this points to inevitable abortion as seen in the table below.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: Missed abortion: In missed abortion, the os will be closed and the patient is usually asymptomatic or has mild spotting
  • Option B: Incomplete abortion: In this the uterine height will be smaller than the POG. Here the uterine height = POG.
  • Option D: Fibroid polyp characteristically presents as intermenstrual bleeding. There will not be any amenorrhea usually. Fibroid polyp can also present as a mass PV.

 

Thus option C; inevitable abortion is correct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Page no 351, William’s 25th edition

choices.text: Incomplete abortion
Inevitable abortion
Threatened abortion

questions.text: A 23 y P2L2 comes to the OPD. She says that she missed her period by 10 days and is now complaining of spotting. There is also mild abdominal pain. On examination the uterus is 6 weeks size and the os is closed. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Threatened abortion

 

  • There is no passage of fleshy mass which rules out complete abortion and incomplete abortion.
  • The os is closed and hence the answer is threatened abortion and not inevitable abortion in which the os will be open.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Page no 349, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Blood clots in the endometrial cavity
Heteroechoic contents seen in the uterine cavity
Normal endometrial lining
The gestational sac seen low down in the uterine cavity

questions.text: A 25y old P2L2 presents with history suggestive of a complete abortion. What would be the expected finding on doing an ultrasound?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Normal endometrial lining

 

In a complete abortion, the ultrasound will be normal, i.e. nothing will be seen inside the endometrial cavity

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ultrasound findings in different abortions are as given below:

 

 

Ref: Page No: 159 DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics; 9th edition

choices.text: Parental balanced translocation

questions.text: The most common cause for spontaneous first trimester abortion is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Chromosomal Aneuploidy

 

The commonest cause of a spontaneous first trimester abortion is a chromosomal aneuploidy

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Page no. 347, William’s 25th edition

questions.text: The single most specific chromosomal anomaly seen in spontaneous abortions is?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Monosomy X

 

The most common single specific chromosomal anomaly seen in spontaneous abortions is monosomy X (45XO)

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Page no. 347, William’s 25th edition

questions.text: All the following have been implicated in spontaneous abortion except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Subclinical hyperthyroidism

 

Subclinical hyperthyroidism is not implicated in causing spontaneous abortion

 

The endocrine disorders implicated in causing spontaneous abortion are:

 

  1. Uncontrolled diabetes mellitus
  2. Overt hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism
  3. Subclinical hypothyroidism with antithyroid antibodies
  4. Luteal phase defect
  5. PCOS

 

Educational Objective:

 

The endocrine disorders implicated in causing spontaneous abortion are:

 

  1. Uncontrolled diabetes mellitus
  2. Overt hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism
  3. Subclinical hypothyroidism with antithyroid antibodies
  4. Luteal phase defect
  5. PCOS

 

Ref: Page no. 347, Williamâ€™s 25th edition

choices.text: The most probable cause could have been a chromosomal abnormality in the fetus and the chance of it recurring is very low
The most probable cause could have been a chromosomal abnormality in the fetus and the chance of it recurring is very high
The most probable cause could have been a balanced translocation in either parent and the chance of it recurring is very low
The most probable cause could have been a balanced translocation in either parent and the chance of it recurring is very high

questions.text: A woman has come for pre-conceptional counselling. She has earlier had a history of 1 spontaneous abortion at 6 weeks and she is very anxious and asks what could have been a possible reason. What will you counsel the woman?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. The most probable cause could have been a chromosomal abnormality in the fetus and the chance of it recurring is very low

 

  • The most common cause of abortions in the first trimester are chromosomal abnormalities in the fetus. The chance of these recurring is very less.
  • In recurrent pregnancy losses, the most common genetic cause of RPL is balanced translocations (parental) and the chance of an abortion occurring is 25%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most common cause of abortions in the first trimester are chromosomal abnormalities in the fetus. The chance of these recurring is very less.
  • In recurrent pregnancy losses, the most common genetic cause of RPL is balanced translocations (parental) and the chance of an abortion occurring is 25%.

 

Ref: Page no. 347 & 352, William’s 25th edition

questions.text: A 24 y primigravida comes to the OPD. She is 5 weeks pregnant and complains of spotting PV. She is not willing for a vaginal examination. A transvaginal ultrasound reveals the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Threatened abortion

 

  • At 5 weeks pregnancy, a TVS should show an intrauterine gestational sac which is seen in the image hence this is a threatened abortion

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: In a complete abortion, the uterine cavity will be empty
  • Option B: In an ectopic pregnancy, a pseudo sac or an empty intra-uterine cavity may be seen
  • Option C: In an incomplete abortion, retained products of conception will be seen

 

Educational Objective:

 

A yolk sac appears within the g. sac at 5.5 weeks

 

An embryo with cardiac activity within the g. sac at 6 weeks.

 

An Ectopic pregnancy will present on TVS as

 

  • No evidence of intrauterine pregnancy
  • Sometimes a pseudo sac is seen intra-uterine
  • Adnexal mass seen
    • G sac with or without yolk sac/ embryo
    • Heterogenous mass in the adnexa (blob sign)
    • Ring like structure in the adnexa (Bagel sign)

 

 

 

Ref: Page no. 159, William’s 25th edition

questions.text: The most common trisomy causing spontaneous abortion is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Trisomy 16

 

The most common trisomy causing spontaneous abortions is Trisomy 16

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Page no. 347, William’s 25th edition

questions.text: Chromosomal abnormalities are implicated as the cause in what percentage of spontaneous first trimester abortions?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 50%

 

Chromosomal abnormalities are implicated in about 54% of spontaneous first trimester abortions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Page no. 347, William’s 25th edition

choices.text: 10 mm
15 mm
20 mm
25 mm

questions.text: An anembryonic pregnancy is described on transvaginal scan when the embryo is absent at a mean sac diameter of:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 25 mm

 

  • Anembryonic pregnancy is diagnosed on TVS when the mean sac diameter (MSD) is 25 mm and there is no embryo.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Anembryonic pregnancy is diagnosed on TVS when the mean sac diameter (MSD) is 25 mm and there is no embryo.

 

Ref: Page no 352; William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Crown – Rump length (CRL)

questions.text: The first anatomical structure to appear in the gestational sac on ultrasound is?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Yolk sac

 

  • On TVS, an intrauterine gestational sac appears at 5 weeks
  • At 5.5 weeks, a yolk sac is seen which is the first anatomical structure to appear in the gestational sac
  • At 6 weeks, an embryo with cardiac activity is seen

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • On TVS, an intrauterine gestational sac appears at 5 weeks
  • At 5.5 weeks, a yolk sac is seen which is the first anatomical structure to appear in the gestational sac
  • At 6 weeks, an embryo with cardiac activity is seen

 

Ref: Page 183, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Grade 1 septic abortion
Grade 2 septic abortion
Grade 3 septic abortion
Grade 4 septic abortion

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency with high grade fever, abdominal pain and purulent vaginal discharge. She gives history of an attempted termination of pregnancy by an unqualified person. On examination, there is generalized guarding and rigidity. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Grade 3 septic abortion

 

  • The scenario described is a grade 3 septic abortion as features of generalized peritonitis are there
  • Clinical grading of septic abortion:
    • Grade 1: Localized to the uterus
    • Grade 2: Pelvic spread
    • Grade 3: Generalized peritonitis, septicemia, endotoxic shock

 

Educational Objective:

 

Septic Abortion:

 

  • Any type of abortion with clinical evidence of infection of the uterus and its contents
  • Criteria:
    • Fever with temperature ≥ 100.4° for > 24 h
    • Purulent vaginal discharge
    • Lower abdominal pain/ tenderness
  • Clinical Grading
    • Grade 1: Localized to the uterus
    • Grade 2: Pelvic spread
    • Grade 3: Generalized peritonitis, septicemia, endotoxic shock
  • Treatment: Broad spectrum antibiotics + Evacuation
  • Indications for Laparotomy:
    • Uterine perforation
    • Suspected intestinal injury
    • Foreign body in abdomen
    • Intra-abdominal abscess
    • Septicemic shock not improving on conservative treatment.

 

Ref: Page no 158, DC Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics 9th edition

questions.text: As per the WHO, abortion is defined as pregnancy loss or termination before:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 20 weeks

 

  • The WHO and the CDC define abortion as pregnancy loss or termination before 20 weeks or with a fetus < 500g

 

Ref: Williamâ€™s Obstetrics 25th edition; page no 346

choices.text: 1 or more consecutive abortions
5 or more consecutive abortions
3 or more consecutive abortions

questions.text: Recurrent pregnancy loss is defined by?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 3 or more consecutive abortions

 

Recurrent Pregnancy Loss (RPL) is classically defined as: 3 or more recurrent abortions but the American Society for Reproductive medicine (2013) now defines RPL as 2 or more failed pregnancies confirmed by USG/HPE.

 

  • Primary RPL is if the woman has never had a live birth
  • Secondary RPL: multiple losses in a patient with a prior live birth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recurrent Pregnancy Loss (RPL) is classically defined as: 3 or more recurrent abortions but the American Society for Reproductive medicine (2013) now defines RPL as 2 or more failed pregnancies confirmed by USG/HPE.

 

  • Primary RPL is if the woman has never had a live birth
  • Secondary RPL: multiple losses in a patient with a prior live birth.

 

Ref: Page no 352, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Increases with increasing maternal age
Decreases with increasing maternal age
Is unaffected by maternal age
There is no clear correlation between pregnancy loss and maternal age

questions.text: In Recurrent Pregnancy Loss, the chance of a successful live birth:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Decreases with increasing maternal age

 

  • Chance of successful pregnancy reduces with increasing no of losses.
  • Chance of successful pregnancy reduces with increasing age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Recurrent Pregnancy loss

 

  • Chance of successful pregnancy reduces with increasing no of losses.
  • Chance of successful pregnancy reduces with increasing age.

 

Ref: Page no 352, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: A 26y old gives a history of two 1st trimester abortions following delivery of a preterm baby at 30 weeks due to severe preeclampsia. She is anxious and wants to be evaluated preconceptionally. Which of the following investigation will you advise?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lupus anticoagulant

 

Based on the history, Antiphospholipid antibody Syndrome is probable. Hence the investigation of choice is Lupus Anticoagulant.

 

Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome

 

  • Commonly presents as RPL
  • Diagnosed based on Sapporo’s Criteria which has Lab and Clinical criteria -At least one clinical and 1 lab criteria must be present for diagnosis.

 

Clinical Criteria

 

Obstetric

 

  • One or more unexplained death of a morphologically normal fetus > 10 weeks

 

OR

 

  • Severe preeclampsia or placental insufficiency necessitating delivery before 34 weeks

 

OR

 

  • 3 or more consecutive spontaneous abortions before 10 weeks

 

Vascular

 

  • 1 or more episode of arterial/venous or small vessel thrombosis in any tissue or organ

 

Lab Criteria (Present on 2 or more occasions at least 12 weeks apart)

 

  • Presence of lupus anticoagulant

 

OR

 

  • Medium to high titers of IgG or IgM anticardiolipin Antibodies

 

OR

 

  • Anti β2 glycoprotein – IgG or IgM Antibody

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome

 

  • Commonly presents as RPL
  • Diagnosed based on Sapporo’s Criteria which has Lab and Clinical criteria -At least one clinical and 1 lab criteria must be present for diagnosis.

 

Clinical Criteria

 

Obstetric

 

  • One or more unexplained death of a morphologically normal fetus > 10 weeks

 

OR

 

  • Severe preeclampsia or placental insufficiency necessitating delivery before 34 weeks

 

OR

 

  • 3 or more consecutive spontaneous abortions before 10 weeks

 

Vascular

 

  • 1 or more episode of arterial/venous or small vessel thrombosis in any tissue or organ

 

Lab Criteria (Present on 2 or more occasions at least 12 weeks apart)

 

  • Presence of lupus anticoagulant

 

OR

 

  • Medium to high titers of IgG or IgM anticardiolipin Antibodies

 

OR

 

  • Anti β2 glycoprotein – IgG or IgM Antibody

 

Ref: Page no 353, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: A woman comes to the Gynae OPD for pre-conceptional counseling, with history of two second trimester abortions. What is the next investigation you will advise?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. TVS

 

  • The most common cause of 2nd trimester RPL are anatomical.
  • The initial investigation for anatomical abnormalities is a transvaginal ultrasound as it is non invasive.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Hysteroscopy: Though this is a good investigation for some Mullerian anomalies and also helps look at other uterine pathologies like uterine polyps and submucosal fibroids, it is not usually performed as an initial test.
  • Endometrial biopsy: This will not give any additional information and is useful in scenarios of abnormal uterine bleeding
  • Chromosomal abnormalities: These are not a common cause of recurrent pregnancy loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most common cause of 2nd trimester RPL are anatomical.
  • The initial investigation for anatomical abnormalities is a transvaginal ultrasound as it is non invasive.

 

Ref: Page no 352, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: Parental chromosomal abnormalities account for what percent of cases of recurrent pregnancy loss?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 2 – 4%

 

Parental Chromosomal Abnormalities:

 

  • Mainly cause 1st trimester RPL
  • 2 - 4%
  • Less significant in RPL; most common in spontaneous abortions
  • Most common: BALANCED TRANSLOCATION (Risk: 25%)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parental Chromosomal Abnormalities:

 

  • Mainly cause 1st trimester RPL
  • 2 - 4%
  • Less significant in RPL; most common in spontaneous abortions
  • Most common: BALANCED TRANSLOCATION (Risk: 25%)

 

Ref: Page no 352, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome
Luteal phase defect
Parental chromosomal abnormalities

questions.text: A 30-year-old G4A3 presents to the OPD with a history of recurrent, painless abortions, each occurring in the mid trimester. The most probably cause is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cervical insufficiency

 

Cervical Insufficiency

 

  • Typically presents as recurrent painless 2nd trimester loss

 

Other Options:

 

  • Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome: This typically presents as pregnancy losses which can be any trimester but there is usually a history of 1st trimester losses or a loss in the 3rd trimester due to severe preeclampsia or abruption
  • Luteal phase defect: This usually presents as recurrent 1st trimester abortions
  • Parental chromosomal abnormalities: This is a very rare cause of recurrent 1st trimester abortions

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cervical insufficiency typically presents as recurrent painless 2nd trimester abortions

 

  • Etiology
  • Congenital
    • Inherited weakness of cervix
    • Associated with uterine anomalies/ DES exposure
  • Acquired: Previous cervical trauma:
    • Dilatation and curettage
    • Conization of cervix
    • Cervical amputation (part of Fothergill surgery)
    • Trachelectomy
    • Cervical tears during a previous delivery.

 

Ref: Page 354, William’s Obstetrics, 25th edition

choices.text: History of 3 or more recurrent, painless 2nd trimester abortions
Cervical length < 25 mm at 14 weeks with a history of an earlier preterm birth
Painless dilated cervix on examination before 24 weeks
Previous history of a preterm birth at 32 weeks

questions.text: All are indications for doing a cervical cerclage except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Previous history of a preterm birth at 32 weeks

 

A previous h/o a preterm birth without a short cervix in the current pregnancy is an indication for starting her on progesterone and no a direct indication for a cerclage

 

Educational Objective:

 

Indications for Cervical Cerclage

 

 

  • History Indicated means: 3 or more previous 2nd trimester/ preterm births
  • USG indicated means
    • H/o 1 or more preterm/ mid-trimester birth with USG cervical length < 25 mm

 

(Not recommended only for short cervical length with no h/o preterm/ mid-trimester birth; Also, not recommended for only funneling seen with no shortening of cervical length)

 

  • Examination indicated means painless mid-trimester cervical dilatation.

  

Ref: Page no 354, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: Which type of cervical cerclage is physiologically the most correctly placed?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Transabdominal cerclage

 

A Trans abdominal cerclage is nearest to the internal os and hence physiologically the most correctly placed cerclage

 

Other options:

 

  • McDonald cerclage is the most commonly performed cerclage but is the least physiological
  • Wurm Cerclage: It is usually done with a U or mattress sutures and is of benefit when there is minimal amount of cervix left.
  • Lash procedure: It is done in the non-pregnant state. Typically done after cervical trauma has caused an anterior  anatomical defect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Transvaginal cervical cerclage
    • McDonald (purse string suture around the cervix)
    • Shirodkar (cerclage after pushing the bladder up so the suture placement is more cephalad I.e., nearer to the os)
    • Sutures are removed at 37 weeks (term)
  • Transabdominal cerclage (via laparotomy or laparoscopy)
    • Physiologically this suture is physiologically closest to the internal os
    • Indicated in transvaginal route failures
    • Delivery is always be cesarean

choices.text: McDonald Cerclage

questions.text: Identify this procedure:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. McDonald Cerclage

 

  • Procedure:
    • Transvaginal cervical cerclage
      • McDonald (purse string suture around the cervix)
      • Shirodkar (cerclage after pushing the bladder up so the suture placement is more cephalad I.e., nearer to the os)
      • Sutures are removed at 37 weeks (term)
    • Transabdominal cerclage (via laparotomy or laparoscopy)
      • Physiologically this suture is physiologically closest to the internal os
      • Indicated in transvaginal route failures
      • Delivery is always be cesarean

 

 

Ref: Page no 356, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: Identify the procedure:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Shirodkar Cerclage

 

The image shows the technique of a Shirodkar cerclage

 

Other options:

 

  • McDonal cerclage is a purse string suture placed transvaginally
  • Wurm Cerclage: It is usually done with a U or mattress sutures and is of benefit when there is minimal amount of cervix left.
  • Lash procedure: It is done in the non pregnant state. Typically done after cervical trauma has caused an anterior  anatomical defect

 

Educational Objective:

 

Procedure:

 

Transvaginal cervical cerclage

 

  • McDonald (purse string suture around the cervix)
  • Shirodkar (cerclage after pushing the bladder up so the suture placement is more cephalad I.e., nearer to the os)
  • Sutures are removed at 37 weeks (term)

 

Transabdominal cerclage (via laparotomy or laparoscopy)

 

  • Physiologically this suture is physiologically closest to the internal os
  • Indicated in transvaginal route failures
  • Delivery is always be cesarean

 

 

Ref: Page no 356, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Antiphospholipid Antibody syndrome
Diabetes in pregnancy
Twin to twin transfusion syndrome

questions.text: Sapporo’s Criteria is used to diagnose:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Antiphospholipid Antibody syndrome

 

Sapporo criteria is used to diagnose APLA syndrome

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Page no 353, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Low dose aspirin to be started immediately
Low dose aspirin and unfractionated heparin to be started immediately
Start LMWH immediately and low dose aspirin once cardiac activity appears
Start low dose aspirin immediately and LMWH once cardiac activity appears

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman with a history of recurrent pregnancy loss was diagnosed as having antiphospholipid antibody syndrome. She is now 6 weeks pregnant. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Start low dose aspirin immediately and LMWH once cardiac activity appears

 

The treatment of APLA in pregnancy is to start low dose aspirin immediately and LMWH once cardiac activity appears

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Reason for pregnancy loss in APLA is mainly by inhibition of trophoblast function and differentiation leading to placental dysfunction.
  • Management of APLA
    • Low dose aspirin as soon as pregnancy is confirmed
    • Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) once cardiac activity appears.

 

Ref: Page no 353, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: Which type of leiomyoma can cause recurrent pregnancy loss?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Submucosal

 

A submucosal fibroid can cause recurrent pregnancy loss as it is within the uterine cavity and can hamper implantation of the embryo

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anatomical causes of RPL:

 

  1. Fibroids (submucosal)
  2. Uterine anomalies
  3. Asherman Syndrome
  4. Cervical insufficiency

 

Thus, option C) Submucosal fibroids which cause distortion of the endometrial cavity cause RPL while subserosal and intramural fibroids do not typically cause recurrent pregnancy losses.

 

Ref: Page no 352, William’s obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: A 34-year woman presents with 3 first trimester abortions. Prior to this, she gives a history of a dilatation and curettage several years earlier and also complains of hypomenorrhea. She has come for pre-conceptional counselling. What would be the most appropriate investigation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hysteroscopy

 

  • The most likely diagnosis in this patient (h/o RPL, hypomenorrhea with a history of curettage) is Asherman syndrome.
  • Uterine synechiae (Asherman syndrome) usually results from destruction of large areas of endometrium
  • This usually follows curettage.
  • Asherman syndrome can be diagnosed on HSG or saline infusion salpingography (multiple filling defects) or hysteroscopy. Treatment is hysteroscopic adhesiolysis.

 

Thus, the most appropriate investigation for this patient is a hysteroscopy.

 

Other Options

 

  • Transvaginal ultrasound: In Asherman syndrome, a TVS will not give much information and is not the investigation of choice
  • TSH: Thyroid disorders can present with RPL and AUB but the classical history of hypomenorrhea following a h/o D & C favors a diagnosis of Asherman syndrome
  • Lupus anticoagulant: This usually presents as RPL or a h/o thrombosis. Hypomenorrhea does not fit into this diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Uterine synechiae (Asherman syndrome) usually results from destruction of large areas of endometrium
  • This usually follows curettage.
  • Asherman syndrome can be diagnosed on HSG or saline infusion salpingography (multiple filling defects) or hysteroscopy. Treatment is hysteroscopic adhesiolysis

 

Ref: Page no 352, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Dilatation and curettage

questions.text: All the following are risk factors for developing cervical insufficiency except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Endometrial biopsy

 

  • Any procedure involving cervical trauma can lead to cervical insufficiency. An endometrial biopsy would not involve cervical trauma except holding the cervix with a vulsullum so is unlikely to lead to cervical insufficiency

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cervical Insufficiency

 

  • Typically presents as recurrent painless 2nd trimester loss
  • Etiology
    • Congenital
      • Inherited weakness of cervix
      • Associated with uterine anomalies/ DES exposure
    • Acquired: Previous cervical trauma:
      • Dilatation and curettage
      • Conization of cervix
      • Cervical amputation (part of Fothergill surgery)
      • Trachelectomy
      • Cervical tears during a previous delivery

 

Thus, endometrial biopsy which can be performed as an opd /office procedure without any dilatation of cervix will not cause cervical insufficiency.

 

Ref: Page no 355, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Aspirin and low molecular weight heparin

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient with recurrent abortion is diagnosed to have antiphospholipid syndrome. What will be the treatment during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Aspirin and low molecular weight heparin

 

Explanation:

 

Reason for pregnancy loss in APLA is mainly by inhibition of trophoblast function and differentiation leading to placental dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Management of APLA
    • Low dose aspirin as soon as pregnancy is confirmed
    • Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) once cardiac activity appears

 

Ref: Page no 355, Williamâ€™s Obstetrics 25th edition
